instructions: Please answer the following questions honestly, choosing the option that best reflects your likely behavior or preference. There are no right or wrong answers.

questions.questionText: Scenario: Your class is organizing the annual school cultural festival, but funds are limited. How do you contribute to managing the finances?

options.A: Create a detailed budget and track all expenses to stay within limits (Financial Acumen).

options.B: Find ways to cut costs and secure discounts or sponsors to boost the budget (Business Sense).

options.C: Launch a creative fundraising campaign to raise additional money for the event (Entrepreneurial Thinking).

options.D: Prioritize essential expenses and ensure transparency and fairness in all spending (Ethical Reasoning).

questions.questionText: Scenario: Your school business club is tasked with promoting a new eco-friendly product made by students. Which role do you take on?

options.A: Conduct market research and analyze data to identify the target audience (Analytical Thinking).

options.B: Design creative posters and social media content to advertise the product (Creativity).

options.C: Be the spokesperson who pitches the product to classmates and teachers (Communication).

options.D: Manage the budgeting and pricing strategy to ensure the campaign is financially viable (Financial Acumen).

questions.questionText: Scenario: Your school is hosting an entrepreneurship competition where teams propose a new business idea. What role would you prefer on your team?

options.A: Brainstorm innovative ideas and take bold risks to shape the business concept (Entrepreneurial Thinking).

options.B: Calculate costs, revenue projections, and handle the finances for the idea (Financial Acumen).

options.C: Craft and deliver the business pitch to persuade the judges (Communication).

options.D: Organize the team’s tasks and ensure the project stays on schedule (Business Sense).

questions.questionText: Scenario: During a school commerce fair, you discover your friend’s stall is using an exaggerated claim to sell a product. How do you respond?

options.A: Urge your friend to correct the information so customers get an honest description (Ethical Reasoning).

options.B: Help them rephrase the claim into something truthful yet still appealing for sales (Business Sense).

options.C: Stay out of it and focus on your own stall; after all, it’s a competition (Entrepreneurial Thinking).

options.D: Quietly inform a teacher or organizer so they can address it and ensure fair play (Social Interaction).

questions.questionText: Scenario: For a class economics project, your team is stuck because members strongly disagree on the approach. How do you help resolve the impasse?

options.A: Take charge, assign clear roles, and decide on a plan so the team can move forward (Business Sense).

options.B: Facilitate an open discussion to hear everyone’s viewpoint and reach a compromise (Communication).

options.C: Lay out the pros and cons of each idea logically to guide the team toward the best solution (Logical Reasoning).

options.D: Suggest a creative solution that combines elements of each idea to satisfy everyone (Creativity).

questions.questionText: Scenario: You won ₹ 5,000 in a school contest. How do you plan to use this money?

options.A: Save or invest most of it for the future, spending only a little now if needed (Financial Acumen).

options.B: Put it towards starting a small venture or project you’ve been wanting to try (Entrepreneurial Thinking).

options.C: Buy yourself something nice and maybe get gifts for your family or friends (Social Interaction).

options.D: Donate a part of it to a good cause and use the rest responsibly (Ethical Reasoning).

questions.questionText: Scenario: While helping manage your school’s store accounts, you notice a Rs. 100 discrepancy in the records. What is your first reaction?

options.A: Go back through all calculations and receipts to find and fix any mistake (Analytical Thinking).

options.B: Suspect possible misplacement or theft, and quietly gather information or clues (Logical Reasoning).

options.C: Inform the supervising teacher about the issue and offer to help resolve it transparently (Ethical Reasoning).

options.D: Cover the shortfall from your own money or another source to quickly set the accounts right (Business Sense).

questions.questionText: Scenario: Your school canteen raised the price of a snack you buy daily by 20%. How do you react?

options.A: Try to understand the reason for the increase—maybe higher costs or inflation—before deciding if you’ll still buy it (Analytical Thinking).

options.B: Find an alternative: either buy something else or figure out a way to get the snack more cheaply elsewhere (Entrepreneurial Thinking).

options.C: Continue buying it if you really like it, accepting that prices can change with demand and costs (Business Sense).

options.D: Discuss the increase with friends and consider giving feedback to the canteen about the impact on students (Social Interaction).

questions.questionText: Scenario: You are volunteering at a school charity sale and a customer complains that an item they bought is defective. How do you handle it?

options.A: Apologize sincerely and offer a refund or replacement to make sure the customer is happy (Communication).

options.B: Explain logically that the items were sold as-is and try to reassure them it’s a minor issue (Logical Reasoning).

options.C: Think of a creative fix or improvement for the item right there to solve the customer’s problem (Creativity).

options.D: Ask a fellow volunteer or teacher for help so you can address the complaint together (Social Interaction).

questions.questionText: Scenario: Your school store can get a bulk deal on notebooks (buy 100, get 10 free), but the store currently needs only 80 notebooks. What do you advise?

options.A: Calculate the long-term savings versus storage costs to see if the bulk purchase will pay off (Analytical Thinking).

options.B: Take the bulk deal and store the extra notebooks for future use, saving money over time (Entrepreneurial Thinking).

options.C: Buy only the 80 needed to avoid overspending now, since money is tight at the moment (Financial Acumen).

options.D: Try to negotiate with the supplier for a smaller deal or a custom offer that fits your needs (Communication).

questions.questionText: Scenario: You are selling your old textbooks online. A potential buyer is bargaining for a much lower price than you listed. How do you respond?

options.A: Negotiate and try to agree on a middle price that seems fair to both of you (Communication).

options.B: Hold firm on your original price, since you know the books’ value and don’t want to lose money (Financial Acumen).

options.C: Agree to the lower price to sell quickly and not lose the buyer (Entrepreneurial Thinking).

options.D: Offer something extra (like study notes) to justify your original price and convince the buyer (Creativity).

questions.questionText: Scenario: In a group business studies assignment, you can choose the kind of contribution you’ll make. Which role do you prefer?

options.A: Take the lead, organize the team, and ensure everyone does their part on time (Social Interaction).

options.B: Do in-depth research and analysis to provide data and insights for the project (Analytical Thinking).

options.C: Devise creative ideas and design the project’s content or visual aids (Creativity).

options.D: Write up the report and present our findings to the class (Communication).

questions.questionText: Scenario: A friend invites you to invest a small amount of your savings in their new business idea. What do you do?

options.A: Examine their business plan and figures carefully first; I only invest if I’m convinced it will likely succeed (Analytical Thinking).

options.B: Take the chance and invest if the idea sounds exciting, accepting the risk for a possible reward (Entrepreneurial Thinking).

options.C: Decline the offer; I prefer to save my money or put it into something less risky (Financial Acumen).

options.D: Offer to help them with the business (like planning or marketing) instead of investing cash (Social Interaction).

questions.questionText: Scenario: You’re considering a future career related to commerce. Which aspect of the field appeals to you most?

options.A: Dealing with numbers, finances, and economic data (Financial Acumen).

options.B: Designing marketing campaigns and coming up with business ideas (Creativity).

options.C: Networking, negotiating deals, and working directly with clients (Communication).

options.D: Launching and managing my own business venture (Entrepreneurial Thinking).

questions.questionText: Scenario: For an extra credit assignment, you need to analyze a local small business and suggest improvements. How will you approach it?

options.A: Collect and study the business’s financial records and sales data to identify trends or problems (Analytical Thinking).

options.B: Interview the owner and some customers to understand their experiences and perspectives (Communication).

options.C: Observe the business in action and brainstorm a creative new idea or product that could help it grow (Creativity).

options.D: Examine how the business treats customers and employees, focusing on fairness and ethics in their practices (Ethical Reasoning).

questions.questionText: Scenario: Your friend has an online store selling handmade crafts and asks you for ideas to boost sales. What do you suggest?

options.A: Analyze the store’s sales and website data to see which products or marketing tactics work best, then adjust accordingly (Analytical Thinking).

options.B: Start a creative social media campaign or contest to draw attention and get people talking about the crafts (Creativity).

options.C: Highlight the unique story behind the crafts and interact with customers personally on social media (Social Interaction).

options.D: Keep all promotions honest and emphasize any eco-friendly or ethical aspects of the products to attract value-conscious buyers (Ethical Reasoning).

questions.questionText: Scenario: Your student startup can buy materials from a cheaper supplier with poor environmental practices, or a more expensive eco-friendly supplier. What do you suggest?

options.A: Use the cheaper supplier to minimize costs and maximize profits, at least for now (Business Sense).

options.B: Choose the eco-friendly supplier, because sustainability and ethics come first, even if it costs more (Ethical Reasoning).

options.C: Find a middle path: use the eco-friendly supplier for most things but the cheaper one where it won’t do much harm (Logical Reasoning).

options.D: Get creative – maybe negotiate a better price from the eco-friendly supplier or highlight the green aspect so customers accept higher prices (Creativity).

questions.questionText: Scenario: You’re managing the accounting for a school fundraiser. Last year’s students left a detailed procedure to follow, but you have an idea to improve it. What do you do?

options.A: Stick to the established procedure exactly to avoid any chance of error (Logical Reasoning).

options.B: Apply your new idea right away because you’re confident it will make things more efficient (Entrepreneurial Thinking).

options.C: Follow the old procedure but make a few minor tweaks where you see obvious improvements (Business Sense).

options.D: Run your idea by a teacher or the team first to get feedback before making changes (Communication).

questions.questionText: Scenario: Your school business club’s event made a good profit. The team needs to decide what to do with this extra money. What do you suggest?

options.A: Reinvest most of it into the club for future projects, competitions, or better equipment (Business Sense).

options.B: Donate a large portion to a charity or school cause to give back to the community (Ethical Reasoning).

options.C: Split the funds between improving the club (future events or resources) and donating to charity for a balance (Logical Reasoning).

options.D: Use it to organize a fun team outing or party to reward everyone’s hard work (Social Interaction).

questions.questionText: Scenario: Imagine you start your own business in the future. What would you consider the primary measure of success for your venture?

options.A: Strong profits and continuous financial growth (Financial Acumen).

options.B: Innovative products or services that have a big impact on the market (Creativity).

options.C: A cohesive team and highly satisfied, loyal customers (Social Interaction).

options.D: Operating ethically and positively impacting society (Ethical Reasoning).

questions.questionText: Scenario: In a business plan competition, your teammate presenting your project is struggling to answer a judge’s question. What do you do?

options.A: Step in and answer the question myself to help out, since I know the answer (Communication).

options.B: Whisper some key information or data to my teammate quietly so they can answer (Analytical Thinking).

options.C: Chime in with a creative example or analogy to clarify the point for the judges (Creativity).

options.D: Stay back and let my teammate handle it, to avoid adding confusion with another voice (Logical Reasoning).

questions.questionText: Scenario: In your summer internship, two supervisors each give you a high-priority task to finish by today. How do you handle this situation?

options.A: Figure out which task is more critical and let each supervisor know what can be done by when (Business Sense).

options.B: Analyze both tasks and create an efficient plan to tackle parts of each so I can finish both on time (Analytical Thinking).

options.C: Ask a colleague for help or delegate one task so that both get completed (Social Interaction).

options.D: Concentrate on doing one task really well first, even if it means the other might be a bit late (Ethical Reasoning).

questions.questionText: Scenario: Your school is offering an optional after-school workshop on stock market investing and personal finance. What do you do?

options.A: Enroll right away; I’m eager to learn about investing and analyze how the stock market works (Financial Acumen).

options.B: Join the workshop mainly to meet like-minded people and discuss business ideas (Social Interaction).

options.C: Skip it; I would rather spend that time on a creative project or another hobby (Creativity).

options.D: Attend only if I see it directly benefiting a future career plan or project of mine (Logical Reasoning).

questions.questionText: Scenario: When working on a commerce-related project, which part do you enjoy the most?

options.A: Solving the numerical and data-related aspects, like calculations and analysis (Logical Reasoning).

options.B: Brainstorming creative ideas and innovative solutions (Creativity).

options.C: Interacting with teammates or clients and communicating the plan (Social Interaction).

options.D: Ensuring everything is done correctly, ethically, and according to rules (Ethical Reasoning).

questions.questionText: Scenario: In a classroom debate about a new economic policy, what kind of point are you most likely to bring up?

options.A: Statistics, numbers, or historical data that support my argument (Analytical Thinking).

options.B: How the policy impacts people’s lives and issues of fairness or justice (Ethical Reasoning).

options.C: The effects on businesses and the overall economy in practical terms (Business Sense).

options.D: A creative alternative solution or an unusual perspective that others haven’t mentioned (Creativity).

questions.questionText: Scenario: Your family runs a small shop, and it’s a very busy day. They ask you to help out. What are you most likely to do?

options.A: Manage the cash register and record all the sales accurately (Financial Acumen).

options.B: Assist customers by answering questions and helping them find items (Social Interaction).

options.C: Redesign product displays and make the shop look attractive to draw in more buyers (Creativity).

options.D: Suggest new ideas for the business, like adding popular products or special discounts (Entrepreneurial Thinking).

questions.questionText: Scenario: You run a small but profitable homemade snacks business. To expand production, you could take out a bank loan. What do you decide?

options.A: Go for the loan and expand quickly; it’s a risk, but it could pay off greatly (Entrepreneurial Thinking).

options.B: Take only a small loan or partial funding to expand gradually without too much risk (Business Sense).

options.C: Don’t take a loan; grow the business slowly using your existing profits to stay debt-free (Financial Acumen).

options.D: Hold off on expanding for now; keep the business as it is until you’re more certain (Logical Reasoning).

questions.questionText: Scenario: Your team’s business idea did not win in the entrepreneurship competition finals. How do you react?

options.A: Study the judges’ feedback carefully to understand what we can improve next time (Analytical Thinking).

options.B: Use it as motivation to come back with a better idea; failure is just a learning step (Entrepreneurial Thinking).

options.C: Seek advice from the judges or mentors to learn how we can do better in the future (Communication).

options.D: Feel discouraged and consider focusing on other things; maybe business isn’t my strength (Entrepreneurial Thinking).

questions.questionText: Scenario: You are preparing the final report for a business case competition. Which best describes your approach?

options.A: Check every calculation and detail multiple times to be sure everything is accurate (Analytical Thinking).

options.B: Emphasize making the overall story and presentation engaging, and not worry too much about tiny details (Creativity).

options.C: Structure the report clearly and logically so that it’s very easy to follow (Logical Reasoning).

options.D: Make sure the report is transparent about any limitations and that all sources are properly credited (Ethical Reasoning).

questions.questionText: Scenario: You have the opportunity to attend one of four special commerce-related workshops this summer. Which do you choose?

options.A: An accounting and finance bootcamp to learn about bookkeeping and investments (Financial Acumen).

options.B: A creative marketing and advertising workshop to practice designing campaigns (Creativity).

options.C: An economics research seminar to explore economic theories and data analysis (Analytical Thinking).

options.D: An entrepreneurship incubator program to develop and pitch startup ideas (Entrepreneurial Thinking).

questions.questionText: Scenario: In your internship, you notice a procedure that could be improved, but fixing it isn’t part of your assigned tasks. What do you do?

options.A: Take initiative and develop a better process on my own, then show my supervisor the results (Entrepreneurial Thinking).

options.B: Bring up the idea to my supervisor and offer to help implement the improvement (Communication).

options.C: Stick to my assigned tasks to avoid overstepping or risking a mistake outside my scope (Logical Reasoning).

options.D: Try a small-scale version of the improvement quietly to see if it works before telling anyone (Analytical Thinking).

questions.questionText: Scenario: You hear news that the Indian rupee’s value has significantly fallen against the US dollar. What are you most likely to do?

options.A: Read articles or reports to understand why it happened and what it could lead to (Analytical Thinking).

options.B: Talk with a teacher or parent to get their perspective on what this means (Communication).

options.C: Consider how it might affect businesses, prices, or people’s lives in India (Business Sense).

options.D: I wouldn’t pay much attention; it doesn’t really affect my daily life (Low Interest).

questions.questionText: Scenario: You have two internship offers: one at a large established corporation and another at a small innovative startup. Which do you choose?

options.A: The fast-paced startup, for the excitement, innovation, and broad learning opportunities (Entrepreneurial Thinking).

options.B: The big corporation, for a structured environment and formal training experience (Business Sense).

options.C: Try to split time or do a short stint at both to gain experience in each environment (Creativity).

options.D: Neither; I’d prefer not to take on an internship right now and focus on other things (Low Engagement).

questions.questionText: Scenario: You are working on a lengthy school project (for example, organizing a commerce fair). What motivates you most to work hard on it?

options.A: Achieving concrete results and a successful outcome that I can be proud of (Business Sense).

options.B: Having the chance to express new ideas and be creative (Creativity).

options.C: Knowing that the project will help others or make a positive impact (Ethical Reasoning).

options.D: Learning new skills or solving a challenging problem along the way (Logical Reasoning).

questions.questionText: Scenario: For a major commerce project, you can choose to work alone or in a team. What would you prefer?

options.A: Work with a team, because I enjoy collaborating and exchanging ideas with others (Social Interaction).

options.B: Work with a team, so we can divide tasks and finish the project more efficiently (Business Sense).

options.C: Work alone, so I can control the project and work at my own pace without coordination issues (Logical Reasoning).

options.D: Work alone, because I do my most creative thinking when I’m by myself (Creativity).

questions.questionText: Scenario: For your commerce class final project, you are allowed to choose the topic and format. Which project do you choose to do?

options.A: Analyze financial or economic data to find interesting trends and insights (Analytical Thinking).

options.B: Create a marketing campaign for a product, complete with designs and slogans (Creativity).

options.C: Do a group project where we simulate running a small business, and I can help lead the team (Social Interaction).

options.D: Write a research paper on an ethical issue in commerce, examining different viewpoints (Ethical Reasoning).

questions.questionText: Scenario: You need to pitch a new business idea to potential investors. How would you prefer to communicate your idea?

options.A: Prepare a detailed written proposal or report with thorough analysis (Analytical Thinking).

options.B: Give a persuasive oral presentation to pitch the idea in person (Communication).

options.C: Show an engaging visual presentation or a prototype of the product (Creativity).

options.D: Network and discuss it in casual one-on-one conversations to build interest (Social Interaction).

questions.questionText: Scenario: If you were to start a new extracurricular club related to commerce at your school, which would you choose to start?

options.A: An investment club to learn about stocks and managing money (Financial Acumen).

options.B: An entrepreneurship club where students can develop and pitch startup ideas (Entrepreneurial Thinking).

options.C: A marketing and advertising club to create fun campaigns and designs (Creativity).

options.D: A social enterprise club to work on business projects that help the community (Ethical Reasoning).

questions.questionText: Scenario: On the day of a big business presentation, your computer crashes and you lose some of your work. How do you respond?

options.A: Stay calm and logically figure out how to recover or quickly redo the lost parts (Logical Reasoning).

options.B: Reach out to teammates or friends immediately to help recover backups or redo the work together (Social Interaction).

options.C: Wing it creatively during the presentation, using whatever material I remember and engaging improvisation (Creativity).

options.D: Explain the situation honestly to the judges or audience and present what I can, showing I can handle adversity (Ethical Reasoning).

questions.questionText: Scenario: Which of these extracurricular activities sounds most appealing to you?

options.A: Debate club or Model United Nations, where I can discuss and persuade (Communication).

options.B: Art, design, or photography club, where I can create and express myself (Creativity).

options.C: Math or economics club, where I can solve problems and analyze data (Analytical Thinking).

options.D: Business or entrepreneurship club, where I can plan ventures and take the lead (Entrepreneurial Thinking).
